Solutions to polynomial equations

With the introduction of complex numbers we can now obtain solutions to those polynomial equations which may have real solutions, complex solutions or a combination of real and complex solutions. For example, the simple quadratic equation \(x^2+16=0\) can be rearranged as \(x^2=-16\) and then taking square roots we see that \(x=\pm\sqrt{-16}=\pm4\sqrt{-1}=\pm 4i\) where we are replacing \(\sqrt{-1}\) by the symbol ‘\(i\)’.

This approach can be extended to the general quadratic equation \(ax^2+bx+c=0\) with roots \(\displaystyle{x=\dfrac{-b\pm\sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a}}\) so that if for example \(3x^2+2x+2=0\) then solving for \(x\):

\[\begin{aligned} x&={-2\pm \sqrt{4-4(3)(2)}\over {2(3)}}\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\\ &={-2\pm \sqrt{-20}\over {6}}= {-2\pm i\sqrt{20}\over {6}} \\\end{aligned}\]

so, \(\large(\)as \(\displaystyle{\frac{\sqrt{20}}{6}=\frac{2\sqrt{5}}{6}=\frac{\sqrt{5}}{3}}\)\(\large)\), the two roots are \(\displaystyle{-{\frac13} +\frac{\sqrt{5}}{3}i}\) and \(\displaystyle{-{\frac13} -\frac{\sqrt{5}}{3}i}\).

In this example we see that the two solutions (roots) are complex conjugates of each other. In fact this will always be the case if the polynomial equation has coefficients: that is, if any complex roots occur they will always occur in complex conjugate pairs.
